bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Maria Teresa Rojas and Lydia Cabrera, January 5, 1953

div1.p: Hench requests that Rojas and Cabrera give a copy of an article by Agramonte to Nogueira. He comments on a recent interview he gave.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Maria Teresa Rojas and Lydia Cabrera, January 5, 1953
div1.opener:
January 5, 1953
Senorita Maria Teresa Rojas and Senorita Lidia Cabrera
Quinta San Jose
Calzada Reel y Manuel Gomez
Marianao, Habana, Cuba
My dear Friends:
div1.p:
When I visited you this time you may recall that I brought with me a copy
of the article by Doctor Agramonte, published in December 1915 in the
SCIENTIFIC MONTHLY, describing the location of Camp Lazear, and so on.
When I was about to present it to Tina she said she thought I had already
given her one, whereupon having described it, I gave it to Lidia. Later
that week I found that I had never given a copy to Doctor Nogueira. I had
merely sent him one or two photostated pages. He is very anxious to have
a complete copy because it is the only place in the American literature
which gives officially the location of Camp Lazear. I think he hopes
eventually to display it inside the caseta.

On my return I tried to find another copy but apparently the one I brought
to you was my last extra copy and the one I have is podly marked up, other-
wise I could photostate it. Under the circumstances, would you be willing,
after making sure that you really do have another copy, to either give or
lend the second copy to Doctor Nogueira? Meanwhile, I shall try to locate
another one through the second-hand book and magazine stores in New York
but it may be months or even much longer before I can find one as it was
very hard for me to find the ones I have already given away.

Professor Baker has just sent me the clippings of the two articles prepared
from the interview which I had with the reporter on Saturday, December 6.
I am sorry that I exhibited impatience but I had, as you know, two more ap-
pointments that afternoon before going to the palace for dinner. I have
not been able to translate the newspaper clippings literally. Professor
baker says there are a number of errors in them but that is almost to be
expected. I am sorry he did not keep his promise and read the articles back
either to you or to Professor Baker.

Lidia, the reference that I meant to show you was to Dr. Francisco Cabrera,
mentioned on page 105 of Finlay's Selected Works. Is he any relative.

Because of the length of the interview with the newspaper reporter, I had no
opportunity to discuss with you the unfinished questionnaire which Tina, your
mother and I started working on a few years ago and never finished. As soon
as I have time, I will write this out and send it to you.

I certainly had a wonderful time with you all and am so sorry that Mary was
not with me. We had a very happy Christmas with our whole family, including
our new son-in-law.
div1.closer: Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
